STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 21, 2022
Renee Adorjan
Washtenaw County DHHS
22 Center St.
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
RE: License #: CP810201490
Washtenaw County DHHS
22 Center St.
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
Dear Mrs. Adorjan:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
10/15/2022. An Exit Conference was held with you on 10/18/2022. Due to the violations,
indicated in the report a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that
violations of any licensing statutes rules are also violations of the MISEP and your
contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 860-0787.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP810201490
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Renee Adorjan, Administrator
Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Washtenaw County DHHS
Facility Address: 22 Center St.
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
Facility Telephone #: (734) 481-8364
Original Issuance Date: 10/05/1994
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s): 10/10/2022, 10/11/2022, 10/14/2022, 10/15/2022

in foster care since last inspection 0 0

Others (please identify person interviewed by role)
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
One of three closed foster home records reviewed showed:
• A reevaluation was due on the foster home in
August/September 2021.
• The foster parent obtained guardianship of the child in
the home on 7/29/2021. It was not known why the
agency did not recommend closure of the foster home’s
license at that time.
• The agency’s recommendation was due 15 days prior to
the foster home’s 9/6/2021 license expiration date. The
recommendation did not occur until 12/2/2021, at which
time the foster home license closed that same date.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021, Renewal 2020.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(f)Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed by the
foster parent and the borrowing agency.
One of three borrowed home records reviewed showed the
foster parent received/signed the information required by (f)
and (g) on 10/3/2022. This was after the child’s 9/9/2022
placement effective date.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021.
2

R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(4) Before completion of the written report required by subrule
(6) of this rule, an agency shall provide the foster parent with a
verbal summary of the preliminary findings at the conclusion of
the evaluation.
One of three special evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation the foster parent was provided a verbal
summary of preliminary findings at the conclusion of the
evaluation. Preliminary findings were denoted in the report as
7/11/2022, which was prior to completion of interviews, and
conclusion on 9/28/2022.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the report.
Two of three special evaluations reviewed did not show
compliance:
• One evaluation did not show clear and consistent
documentation of the interviewer and or place of contact
related to each interview.
• A second record documented a child’s full name in the
report.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
Two of three special evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation of (c) as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021.
3

R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a
foster home, then both of the following shall be documented
before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to the
time of the change in placement and the needs that remain to
be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
One of four closed foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (a) and (b) as required by the rule.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of a dental exam for the child, due by 8/19/2022.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2020.
R 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(a),
shall include all of the following information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404 (4).
(h) The child management plan to be used by the foster
parent.
One of five initial service plans (ISP) reviewed did not show
documentation of (c) and (h) as required by the rule.
(c) is a Repeat Violation- Interim 2021.
4

2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 4.22 MISACWIS (Commitment 22).
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the primary
tracking system and satisfy federal reporting requirements.
In various open foster care and independent living youth records
reviewed, the record did not show uploads of all required
documents. Various documents were provided at exit (i.e.,
signed parent agency treatment plan agreements, signed
service plans, action summaries, program statement verification
and or FTM forms).
ISEP 6.33(5)(c) Assessment and Service Plans, Content (Commitment 69).
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
One of 21 service plans reviewed did not show documentation
of a youth’s signature.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
5

community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as out lined in the following table.
Semi-annual transition meeting Beginning at age 14, semi-
annual transition meetings must occur once every 180-calendar
day to discuss a child’s permanency goal and identify supportive
adults.
Three of six open foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance, as required by the standard:
• One child’s record did not show documentation of a 2021
or 2022 semi-annual transition meeting.
• A second child’s record did not show documentation of
an FTM for the child’s 6/1/2022-8/29/2022 USP. One was
completed outside of the required timeframe on 6/8/2022.
Additionally, this child’s record did not show
documentation of a DHS-1105 for a reported 5/2/2022
FTM.
• A third child’s record did not show documentation of an
FTM for the child’s 2/26/2022-5/252022 USP. One was
completed outside the required timeframe on 4/11/2022.
Additionally, this child’s record did not show
documentation of a FTM related to the child’s various
moves between 2/5/2022 and 9/15/2022.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021.
FOM 722-8 Case Service Plans- Overview, Types, And Timeframes.
Supervisor Approval:
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
One of 21 services plans reviewed were approved 28 days late.
.
6

FOM 722-8D Treatment plans.
Agreement and Signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court
ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
Three of 21 service plans reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child’s 11/5/2021-2/2/2022 USP treatment plan was
not signed by the birth parent until 6/10/2022.
• A second and third child’s record did not show
documentation of the respective child’s 5/20/2022-
6/13/2022 and 5/2/2022- 5/31/202 ISP treatment plan
signed by the caregiver.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021-cite under FOM-722-8C
FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
MiSACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
change.
• Three days prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement
change.
• Within three business days of foster care or juvenile
justice program case closure
One of four closed foster child records, one of three closed
independent living youth (IL) records, and two of six open foster
child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• The closed foster child’s record showed the DHS-69 for
the child’s 3/17/2022 case closure was completed late on
6/27/2022.
• The closed IL youth’s record showed the DHS-69 for the
youth’s 8/15/2022 reported case closure was completed
late on 10/19/2022.
• The first of the two open foster child’s records showed
the DHS-69 for the child’s change of placement to his
7

birth mother on 7/6/2022 was complete late on
7/20/2022.
• The second of the two open foster child records showed
a DHS-69 was not documented for the child’s 9/15/2022
move to Hanley House. Additionally, three of the DHS-
69s completed related this child ‘s replacements
(between 2/5/2022 and 4/22/2022) were completed late
on 3/10/2022, 5/11/2022 and 5/11/2022 respectively.
Each was more than three business day after the
respective date of the change.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021.
FOM 802 Mental Health and Behavioral and Developmental Need of
Children under supervision of MDHHS.
All children entering foster care are required to have a mental
health screening within 30 days of removal. The screening
instrument must be completed by a person who knows the child
best, before the child's Early Periodic, Screening, Diagnostic,
and Treatment (EPSTD)/well child exam.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of a trauma screening for the child, as defined by
the rule.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
R400.12324(2)(a) Reevaluation:
• The agency was apprised the reevaluation assessment shall consistently
document an assessment of the foster parents strengths and weaknesses as
also reported by the foster parents.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Nothing this inspection.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were zero incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
There were one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
8

The incident related an allegation that the foster mother and her adoptive daughter
had a verbal argument that became physical after both parties began to push and
pull each other. The special evaluation revealed the foster parent was attacked by
the adoptive daughter in the present of the two foster youths in the home. The two
foster youths became involved in the altercation and hit and or fought with the
adoptive youth. The incident resulted with the adoptive youth having a scratch to her
lip and eye. The foster home was found in violation of the behavior management
rule, in addition to the unusual incident notification, and foster parent qualification
rules. The foster parent admitted to not calling the police about the incident, calling
the adoptive youth the “B” word; and it was revealed the foster parent did not timely
report the incident to the agency. A corrective action plan was developed with the
foster parent along with safe planning.
The agency adhered to all departmental requirements, except R400.12325(5)(d) as
indicated in this report.
AND
The agency has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2021 Interim inspection where
it received the following violations:
• R400.12212(3)(a) -Personnel records.
• R400.12306(1)-Application request.
• R400.12306(3)(a)-(f)- Application request.
• R400.12324(8)-Reevaluation.
• R400.12326(1)(f) & (g)- Borrowed home.
• R400.12327(5)(d) &(e) Special evaluation.
• R400.12327(6)(c)- Special evaluation.
• R400.12327(7) -Special evaluation.
• MCL 722.120(3) Investigation, Inspection and examination…
• R400.12413(1)(c)(ii)- Medical and dental care policy.
• R400.12418(2)(a) &(b)- Development of service plans.
• R400.12419(1)(c)-Initial service plans.
• R400.12420(1) (g)-Updated service plans.
• R400.12510(2)-Independent living contract.
• ISEP 4.22- MISACWIS (Commitment 22).
• ISEP 6.33- Assessment and service plans, content (Commitment 69).
• ISEP 6.49- Medical passport.
• FOM 722-6B- Family team meeting.
• FOM 722-8C Foster care-parent agency treatment plan & service agreement.
• FOM 722-08E- Foster care/juvenile justice action summary.
In terms of the agency’s 2021 Interim Inspection corrective action plan, the agency
made progress, but was not totally successful with all aspects of the plan. This was
notwithstanding its demonstrated enhanced monitoring tools. The agency provided
9

proof of various oversight tools/efforts implemented. The agency reduced
noncompliance in some areas but not all, as illustrated by the repeat violations cited
in this inspection report.
The agency’s second corrective action plan related to Special Investigation
2022C0420024, initiated 7/20/2022, where it was alleged that the agency, did not
follow policies related to conducting a foster parent’s special evaluation; and created
a barrier to the foster home’s transfer to another child placing agency. Additionally,
that the agency did not inform the child’s foster care worker of the initiated special
evaluation. The agency was found in violation of R400.12327(1)(d) for Special
evaluation. The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan on
10/13/2022. Currently it is too early to determine ongoing compliance, but it is
noteworthy the agency was not cited in this area during this inspection.
The agency’s third corrective action plan related to Special Investigation
2022C0420026, initiated on 8/26/2022 related to an allegation that the agency did not
conclude the foster parent’s special evaluation within 45 days, and had not
communicated with the foster parent since 7/11/2022. The agency was found in
violation of R400.12327(3) for Special evaluation. The agency submitted an
acceptable corrective action plan on 10/5/2022. Currently it is too early to determine
ongoing compliance, but it is noteworthy, the agency was not cited in this area during
this inspection.
DCWL ANAYLST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
There were no safety alerts for the agency during this inspection period.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator’s report dated 10/10/2022 was received and reviewed. The
agency assessed its areas of noncompliance as indicated in the 2021 Interim Inspection
report; and completed all other aspects as required by that document.
Interviews
The chief administrator, section manager and three supervisory staff participated in the
entrance conference and exit conference. The entrance conference centered on a
review and discussion related to the last inspection’s corrective action plan, new staff,
and the agency’s current challenges if any, and status/program functioning. The DCWL
Analyst attended the entrance conference and presented her findings from the
unlicensed relative and foster home visits. The exit conference focused on a summary
of staff interviews, and the result of the inspection/ indicated rule and policy violations.
Three foster workers and one supervisor were interviewed during this inspection.
10

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
________________________________________ October 20, 2022
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 21, 2022
________________________________________
Date
Area Manager
